objnote.p: The book was published in two volumes. The design by Blake reproduced here is the engraved title page to volume 2. This print was copied from Object 17 of Blake's engraved illustrations to Edward Young's *Night Thoughts*, 1797. In the third state of the plate appearing in the issue of *The Seraph* datable to c. 1825-1828, an inscription below the design reads "Conscience & the recording Angel. | Youngs Nt. Thoughts." This accords with the identification of the angel in the "Explanation of the Engravings" in the 1797 *Night Thoughts*: "Conscience represented as a recording angel; who is veiled, and in the act of noting down the sin of intemperance in a bacchanalian."

illustration.illusobjdesc: A winged female angel stands to the right of the text panel. She faces forward with her head turned slightly left; she looks down toward the figure below and to the left. She is gowned and wears a scarf or other drapery over her head. A transparent veil hangs over her face. The figure's hair is long and may be drawn into several braids. The figure holds a tablet or paper in her left hand. Her right hand holds and writes with a pen or pencil. The figure's right foot is visible below the hem of her gown; a line around her foot suggests that she may be wearing sandals. A male with short, curly hair lies or reclines in the lower left portion of the design. Only his upper body is clearly visible. The figure is partly nude and a sheet or other drapery covers his lower body; he may be in a bed. He faces forward with his head turned toward the viewer. His head rests on his right shoulder. He is smiling and his mouth may be open slightly. His right arm is bent and likely supports the figure's weight. He holds a goblet or chalice in his left hand. The background may be a shadowed wall or the sky with clouds.

She is gowned and wears a scarf or other drapery over her head. A transparent veil hangs over her face. The figure's hair is long and may be drawn into several braids. The figure holds a tablet or paper in her left hand. Her right hand holds and writes with a pen or pencil. The figure's right foot is visible below the hem of her gown; a line around her foot suggests that she may be wearing sandals. In the third state of the plate appearing in the issue of c. 1825-1828, an inscription below the design reads "Conscience & the recording Angel. | Youngs Nt. Thoughts."

A male with short, curly hair lies or reclines in the lower left portion of the design. Only his upper body is clearly visible. The figure is partly nude and a sheet or other drapery covers his lower body; he may be in a bed. He faces forward with his head turned toward the viewer. His head rests on his right shoulder. He is smiling and his mouth may be open slightly. His right arm is bent and likely supports the figure's weight. He holds a goblet or chalice in his left hand. He is probably drinking. In the source for the design, the 1797 edition of Edward Young's Night Thoughts with Blake's engravings, this figure is described as "a bacchanalian" in the "Explanation of the Engravings."
The background might represent a sky filled with dark clouds or shadows.
